title: Loch Insh Walk Route

images.title: Chris Haworth / Loch Insh through the trees
images.caption: Loch Insh through the trees

images.title: John S Ross / Loch Insh
images.caption: Looking over the loch towards An Suidhe (541 mtrs), a Strathspey outlier of the Monadliaths

images.title: Peter Bond / Bridge over the Spey at Kincraig
images.caption: Bridge over the Spey at Kincraig

images.title: Richard Webb / Loch Insh
images.caption: Loch on the Spey, with miles of marshland upstream towards Kingussie. Many of the outstanding features of the Cairngorm National Park are visible here. The loch and marshes, the vast forests of Glen Feshie and Inshriach, with the 1100m granite hills of the western Monadh Ruadh beyond. Loch Insh is a popular water sport site, with a popular centre at the downstream end.

images.title: Mick Garratt / Osprey Nest, Loch Insh
images.caption: Osprey Nest, Loch Insh

images.title: Richard Webb / Loch Insh woodlands
images.caption: Loch Insh woodlands. An RSPB managed woodland, and thus safe from the ribbon development that has accelerated in recent years along the Insh road.

images.title: Gordon Brown / The Spey at Loch Insh
images.caption: The Spey at Loch Insh. Barely a ripple on the water as Loch Insh narrows to become the river Spey again. The distant hills lie along Glen Tromie.

images.title: Dorothy Carse / Loch Insh
images.caption: Looking across the southwestern end of the loch towards Creag Mhigeachaidh, Glen Feshie.

description: This walk visits the beautiful Loch Insh near Kincraig in the Caingorms. You can start the walk from the parking area at the north eastern end of the loch. Then walk up to Kincraig Bridge where you can enjoy fine views over the loch and the River Spey. On the way you'll pass the picturesque churchyard of Insh Church which sits right next to the loch. Ospreys are known to nest in the trees around the loch so keep your eyes peeled as you make your way along the paths. There's also a watersports centre so you may see people windsurfing on the water.
